rev.diff:
Line 361: Line 361:
===== 10 February =====
===== 10 February =====
The protests continued at Tahrir Square and the parliament building. 3,000 lawyers marched from the lawyers' syndicate in downtown Cairo to [[Abedeen Palace]], one of the official residences of the president. 1,000 physicians, dressed in white coats, also arrived at Tahrir Square to applause.<ref name="aljazbloglive10feb">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/09/live-blog-feb-10-egypt-protests< |title=Live Blog Feb 10 – Egypt Protests |work=[[Al Jazeera]] |date= |accessdate=10 February 2011}}</ref> Strikes at national industries, including tourism and transportation, continued<ref name="VOA-20110210">{{cite news|url=http://www.voanews.com/english/news/middle-east/Protests-Strikes-Spread-as-Egypts-Regime-Stiffens-115706904.html|title=Protests, Strikes Spread as Egypt's Regime Stiffens|publisher=[[Voice of America]]|date=February 10, 2011|accessdate=February 10, 2011}}</ref> and even spread to Alexandria, Mahalla and Port Said.<ref name="aljazlive">[[Al Jazeera English]]: Breaking News, 2011</ref>{{Full|February 2011}}
The protests continued at Tahrir Square and the parliament building. 3,000 lawyers marched from the lawyers' syndicate in downtown Cairo to [[Abedeen Palace]], one of the official residences of the president. 1,000 physicians, dressed in white coats, also arrived at Tahrir Square to applause.<ref name="aljazbloglive10feb">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/09/live-blog-feb-10-egypt-protests< |title=Live Blog Feb 10 – Egypt Protests |work=[[Al Jazeera]] |date= |accessdate=10 February 2011}}</ref> Strikes at national industries, including tourism and transportation, continued<ref name="VOA-20110210">{{cite news|url=http://www.voanews.com/english/news/middle-east/Protests-Strikes-Spread-as-Egypts-Regime-Stiffens-115706904.html|title=Protests, Strikes Spread as Egypt's Regime Stiffens|publisher=[[Voice of America]]|date=February 10, 2011|accessdate=February 10, 2011}}</ref> and even spread to Alexandria, Mahalla and Port Said.<ref name="aljazlive">[[Al Jazeera English]]: Breaking News, 2011</ref>{{Full|February 2011}}
â   â
[[Al Hurra]] TV reported that Mubarak is to hand his authorities to the Egyptian army.<ref>{{he}}[[Ehud Yaari]], [[Israeli News Company]], [[Channel 2 (Israel)]] [http://www.mako.co.il/news-world/arab/Article-a084cdc90101e21004.htm ×××××¨×§ ××¢×××¨ ××ª ×¡××××××ª×× ××¦××]</ref> General Hassan al-Roueini, the military commander for the Cairo area, told protesters in Tahrir Square, "All your demands will be met today."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110210/D9LA0CHO0.html |title=Military says Mubarak will meet protesters demands |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-10}}</ref> State TV added that Mubarak will speak tonight from his Cairo palace. This comes after Egypt's military proclaimed on television that they have stepped in to "safeguard the country". The ''Associated Press'' suggests a military coup may be occurring. State TV showed Defense Minster [[Field Marshal]] Mohamed Hussein Tantawi meeting with two dozen top army officers. Mubarak and his vice president, Omar Suleiman were not present.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110210/D9LA1S980.html |title=Mubarak meets with VP, protesters flood square |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-10}}</ref> State TV says information minister, Anas el-Fiqqi, denies that Mubarak will resign.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110210/D9LA2IBO0.html |title=Egyptian minister denies Mubarak will step down |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-10}}</ref> Prime Minister Ahmed Shafiq said, "everything is in the hands of President Hosni Mubarak and no decisions have been taken yet."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110210/D9LA2SHO3.html |title=Egypt army takes charge, Mubarak to address nation |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-10}}</ref> Al Arabiya television, citing "trusted sources" just minutes before Mubarak was to speak, said he would transfer his powers to his vice president.<ref>{{cite web|last=Blair |first=Edmund |url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/10/us-egypt-idUSTRE70O3UW20110210 |title=Mubarak to announce handover in speech: TV |publisher=Reuters.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-10}}</ref> Mubarak says he is transferring his power to his vice president, Omar Suleiman.<ref>[http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110210/D9LA55F03.html Egypt's Mubarak transfers power to vice president]</ref> He also said he will request six constitutional amendments and that he would lift emergency laws when security in the country permitted it.<ref>[http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110210/D9LA58F81.html Egypt's Mubarak transfers power to vice president]</ref> Protesters watched in stunned silence or in anger to his speech. Some crying or waving their shoes in the air. As far as the transfer of power is concerned, Mubarak said "I have seen that it is required to delegate the powers and authorities of the president to the vice president as dictated in the constitution,". The constitutional article is used to transfer powers if the president is "temporarily" unable to carry out his duties and does not mean his resignation.<ref>[http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110210/D9LA5CEO2.html Egypt's Mubarak transfers power to vice president]</ref> Mubarak also said he would stay in the country and is "adamant to continue to shoulder my responsibility to protect the constitution and safeguard the interests of the people ... until power is handed over to those elected in September by the people in free and fair elections in which all the guarantees of transparencies will be secured."<ref>[http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110210/D9LA5JD00.html Egypt's Mubarak transfers power to vice president]</ref> More than three million people in Tahrir Square chanted '''Leave! Leave! Leave!''' after Mubarak's speech.<ref>http://parkerspitzer.blogs.cnn.com/2011/02/10/mubarak-says-hes-staying-until-september/</ref> Vice President Omar Suleiman called on the anti-Mubarak protesters to go home.<ref>[http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110210/D9LA5RQO0.html Egypt's Mubarak transfers power to vice president]</ref> Eyewitnesses said that the Egyptian army had pulled out troops from many locations near the presidential palace in Cairo.<ref>[http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/witnesses-egyptian-army-withdraws-positions-near-presidential-palace Witnesses: Egyptian army withdraws from positions near presidential palace]</ref>Soon after the television announcement, a large number of protesters began to march towards the presidential palace<ref>http://online.wsj.com/article/BT-CO-20110210-719857.html</ref> Mohamed ElBaradei is saying "Egypt will explode" because Mubarak refused to step down and ElBaradei is calling on military intervention.<ref>[http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110210/D9LA71380.html ElBaradei calls on Egyptian army to intervene]</ref>
 
{{quotebox|"So I thought I would delegate powers to the vice president, according to the constitution, stipulations of the constitution I know quite well that Egypt, while fighting should try to go out of this juncture, but at the same time the determination of the people is going to help Egypt across this juncture through the perseverance, the honesty of its people, and is going to be above all."|Hosni Mubarak<ref name="Mubarak's stepping down speech">{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/02/10/egypt.mubarak.statement/ |title=Full text of Mubarak's speech |work=[[CNN]]|date=10 February 2011|accessdate=10 February 2011}}</ref>||width = 40%}}
{{quotebox|"So I thought I would delegate powers to the vice president, according to the constitution, stipulations of the constitution I know quite well that Egypt, while fighting should try to go out of this juncture, but at the same time the determination of the people is going to help Egypt across this juncture through the perseverance, the honesty of its people, and is going to be above all."|Hosni Mubarak<ref name="Mubarak's stepping down speech">{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/02/10/egypt.mubarak.statement/ |title=Full text of Mubarak's speech |work=[[CNN]]|date=10 February 2011|accessdate=10 February 2011}}</ref>||width = 40%}}
  +   +
[[Al Hurra]] TV reported that Mubarak is to hand his authorities to the Egyptian army.<ref>{{he}}[[Ehud Yaari]], [[Israeli News Company]], [[Channel 2 (Israel)]] [http://www.mako.co.il/news-world/arab/Article-a084cdc90101e21004.htm ×××××¨×§ ××¢×××¨ ××ª ×¡××××××ª×× ××¦××]</ref> General Hassan al-Roueini, the military commander for the Cairo area, told protesters in Tahrir Square, "All your demands will be met today."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110210/D9LA0CHO0.html |title=Military says Mubarak will meet protesters demands |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-10}}</ref> State TV added that Mubarak will speak tonight from his Cairo palace. This comes after Egypt's military proclaimed on television that they have stepped in to "safeguard the country". The ''Associated Press'' suggests a military coup may be occurring. State TV showed Defense Minster [[Field Marshal]] Mohamed Hussein Tantawi meeting with two dozen top army officers. Mubarak and his vice president, Omar Suleiman were not present.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110210/D9LA1S980.html |title=Mubarak meets with VP, protesters flood square |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-10}}</ref> State TV says information minister, Anas el-Fiqqi, denies that Mubarak will resign.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110210/D9LA2IBO0.html |title=Egyptian minister denies Mubarak will step down |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-10}}</ref> Prime Minister Ahmed Shafiq said, "everything is in the hands of President Hosni Mubarak and no decisions have been taken yet."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110210/D9LA2SHO3.html |title=Egypt army takes charge, Mubarak to address nation |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-10}}</ref> Al Arabiya television, citing "trusted sources" just minutes before Mubarak was to speak, said he would transfer his powers to his vice president.<ref>{{cite web|last=Blair |first=Edmund |url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/10/us-egypt-idUSTRE70O3UW20110210 |title=Mubarak to announce handover in speech: TV |publisher=Reuters.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-10}}</ref> Mubarak says he is transferring his power to his vice president, Omar Suleiman.<ref>[http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110210/D9LA55F03.html Egypt's Mubarak transfers power to vice president]</ref> He also said he will request six constitutional amendments and that he would lift emergency laws when security in the country permitted it.<ref>[http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110210/D9LA58F81.html Egypt's Mubarak transfers power to vice president]</ref> Protesters watched in stunned silence or in anger to his speech. Some crying or waving their shoes in the air. As far as the transfer of power is concerned, Mubarak said "I have seen that it is required to delegate the powers and authorities of the president to the vice president as dictated in the constitution,". The constitutional article is used to transfer powers if the president is "temporarily" unable to carry out his duties and does not mean his resignation.<ref>[http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110210/D9LA5CEO2.html Egypt's Mubarak transfers power to vice president]</ref> Mubarak also said he would stay in the country and is "adamant to continue to shoulder my responsibility to protect the constitution and safeguard the interests of the people ... until power is handed over to those elected in September by the people in free and fair elections in which all the guarantees of transparencies will be secured."<ref>[http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110210/D9LA5JD00.html Egypt's Mubarak transfers power to vice president]</ref> More than three million people in Tahrir Square chanted '''Leave! Leave! Leave!''' after Mubarak's speech.<ref>http://parkerspitzer.blogs.cnn.com/2011/02/10/mubarak-says-hes-staying-until-september/</ref> Vice President Omar Suleiman called on the anti-Mubarak protesters to go home.<ref>[http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110210/D9LA5RQO0.html Egypt's Mubarak transfers power to vice president]</ref> Eyewitnesses said that the Egyptian army had pulled out troops from many locations near the presidential palace in Cairo.<ref>[http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/witnesses-egyptian-army-withdraws-positions-near-presidential-palace Witnesses: Egyptian army withdraws from positions near presidential palace]</ref>Soon after the television announcement, a large number of protesters began to march towards the presidential palace<ref>http://online.wsj.com/article/BT-CO-20110210-719857.html</ref> Mohamed ElBaradei is saying "Egypt will explode" because Mubarak refused to step down and ElBaradei is calling on military intervention.<ref>[http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110210/D9LA71380.html ElBaradei calls on Egyptian army to intervene]</ref>
Contradicting reports from various media sources around the world state that either Suleiman or Tantawi is expected to take over.<ref> [http://www.globes.co.il/news/article.aspx?did=1000622357 ××¦×¨×× ×××¨× ×××©××¨ ×¦×××? ×××××¨×§ ×¦×¤×× ×××ª×¤××¨ ××¢×¨×],Israel's [[Globes]] newspaper, 2 February 2011</ref>
Contradicting reports from various media sources around the world state that either Suleiman or Tantawi is expected to take over.<ref> [http://www.globes.co.il/news/article.aspx?did=1000622357 ××¦×¨×× ×××¨× ×××©××¨ ×¦×××? ×××××¨×§ ×¦×¤×× ×××ª×¤××¨ ××¢×¨×],Israel's [[Globes]] newspaper, 2 February 2011</ref>
